bioghist.p: In 1884 an organization was formed and named Morton Street Day Nursery and Free Kindergarten with a later change to Morton Street Day Nursery and Working People's Aid, Inc. In 1920 a different organization was formed under the name of Americanization Committee of Germantown to provide language and culture instruction to immigrants. Changes in this organization's concerns lead to a name change to Germantown Community Center. In October, 1934, the Morton Street Day Nursery and Germantown Community Center merged to form the Germantown Settlement with headquarters at 324 High Street. Over the years the Settlement has provided a variety of services to constituents within its service area. This includes community organization within the Morton area and the provision of services to the elderly. A branch office in the Wister area was opened in 1957 at 48 E. Penn Street. A satellite office was later opened in the Olney area.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of organizational records for Germantown Settlement. Many of the papers appear to have come from the office of Emanuel V. Freeman, Executive Director. The collection contains minutes of the Board of Directors, with agendas and committee reports (1969-1986), as well as minutes of staff meetings and various Settlement programs. Office files include: financial records such as check registers, expense reports, budgets, purchase orders, and receipts; personnel policies; personnel files; and work schedules and time sheets. Program records include planning and financial records for Late Start, Day Camp programs, Children's Learning Center, and Transit Aide, as well as records related to renovations of Settlement houses. There are a significant number of Settlement case records and referrals from the 1980s, in addition to client intake forms and assistance records for the Corporation for Aging. The collection also contains records of the Germantown Settlement's involvement in various community development programs and organizations, such as the Greater Philadelphia Federation of Settlements, the Philadelphia Corporation for Aging, the Office of Housing and Community Development, the Philadelphia Development Partnership, and the Philadelphia Civic Center. These records include minutes, correspondence and memoranda, reports, and newsletters. The collection also contains scrapbooks of clippings from the 1950s.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
